h4. Current Behavior
Currently, the log analyzer in Confluence scans only {{atlassian-confluence.log}}, and does not examine the contents of {{atlassian-confluence.log.1}}, {{atlassian-confluence.log.2}}, etc.

h4. Problem
In cases where the log fills up quickly with errors, crucial error messages may be pushed to later, numbered log files. For example, {{atlassian-confluence.log}} might contain logs from the past 4 hours, while {{atlassian-confluence.log.1}} contains a defining error that happened 5 hours ago. Log scanner will not pick up this error, and the user will have to find it manually or diagnose the issue through other troubleshooting methods.

h4. Proposed solution
If {{atlassian-confluence.log}} contains only recent logs, scan more log files. For example, if the earliest log in {{atlassian-confluence.log}} is only from 4 hours ago, continue scanning more logs until you hit a log that is _X_ days old.
fields.summary: Log analyzer should scan based on date when a single log file isn't enough

 # Login to Confluence with administrator account

 # Click any of the add-on's name and you will be directed to a search page to allow more search filters to be applied

The search result should be filtered to fit the selected criteria from the _Last Modified_ once the criteria is clicked
h3. Actual Results

Clicking any criteria from the _Last Modified_ will not trigger the search result to change
h3. Notes

If user is searching usage for a specific macro in the Confluence search bar (for example: {{macroName:profile}}), clicking on the _Last Modified_ filter at the left will always trigger the search result to change.
h3. Workaround

Searching the add-on using {{macroName:}} and type the macro name after the colon. For example, to search for all excerpt-include macros:
{noformat}
macroName:excerpt-include*
{noformat}

h3. Problem Definition
When setting up Confluence Data Center and using 1 network interface, you get the following warning message
{quote}
Your Confluence host has a one network interface only. For optimal cluster performance we recommend the use of a second network interface for cluster communication between Confluence nodes.
{quote}
This message is correct for non-virtual environments. However, when we have VMs running the nodes, it doesn't make a lot of sense to ask to have 2 network interfaces. Both of those will map down to a single physical network interface.

h3. Suggested Solution
Clarify this message to target physical cluster nodes and not VMs.
fields.summary: Improve In-Product warning in cluster configuration for the number of network interfaces

h3. Summary

Clicking an attached PDF to view renders slowly in IE11 and Safari, and much faster in Chrome and Firefox.  This seems to be related to the open bug report in PDF.js.  [https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/issues/7431]
h3. Environment

Tested with the following browsers all from the same client machine, all accessing the same PDF / Confluence host instance.

Chrome v.58:   ~2 sec
Firefox v.24.0:  ~2 sec
IE 11:                ~20+ sec

I tested the client side using Win 2008 on one of our internal VM's which have Chrome, Firefox, and IE11 installed.  

The Confluence host side I tested a fresh install of Confluence 6.2.0 installed on my Mac.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

*To create the environment*
 # Start Confluence (most recent version is fine.)
 # Create new or access an existing page
 # Attach the customer's PDF from the ticket (drag-and-drop to attach)
 # Save the page

*To test rendering the PDF preview from different browsers*
 # Navigate to the page that includes the embedded PDF
 # Click the PDF on the page when in View mode (not Edit mode)
 # Take note of the time taken to render and display the PDF

h3. Expected Results

Same rendering time between all browsers
h3. Actual Results

IE11 performs ~10x slower than Chrome or Firefox
h3. Notes
 * See attached video.

h3. Workaround
 * None.
 * Wait for the page to render or use Chrome or Firefox which render the PDFs quickly.

h3. Summary

Back button in browser does not return to previous page when using URL with anchor link
h3. Environment
 * Any browser
 * Confluence 6.2.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create Page A with content that scrolls beyond the bottom of the screen, with several headings in the content that also go below the fold
 # Add a table of content macro at the top of Page A
 # Create Page B and insert *Web Links* with anchors from the table of contents to point to headings on Page A after the fold, for example
 ** [http://confluence.mycompany.com/display/CONF/PageA#HeadingSix]
 # Save Page B
 # Click on the link to go to Page A with the anchor
 # Click the back button in the broswer

h3. Expected Results

The browser goes back to page
h3. Actual Results

You need to click twice to return to the previous page
h3. Notes

fields.description:
In one of our plugins, we are currently using an index schema to add content properties to the search index of Confluence, as documented here: [Content Properties in the REST API|https://developer.atlassian.com/confdev/confluence-server-rest-api/content-properties-in-the-rest-api]

This works perfectly when inserting/updating content properties. Unfortunately, due to problems with the search index in our Confluence instance, we had to rebuild the search indexes as documented here: [Rebuilding the search index|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/content-index-administration-148844.html#ContentIndexAdministration-Rebuildingthesearchindex]

Now after the reindex, all content properties were not present in the index anymore. They are still attached to the content, but not in the index anymore. Only after updating the content properties, they were being indexed again.
h2. Steps to reproduce
 # Install a fresh instance of Confluence. (We were able to reproduce this with version 5.8.10 and 5.10.6)
 # Choose "Example Site" to init the instance with the Demonstration Space.
 # Install the attached test plugin. All it does is defining the following index schema:
{code:xml}
<content-property-index-schema key="test-plugin-content-property-index-schema">
    <key property-key="metadata">
        <extract path="likes" type="number" />
    </key>
</content-property-index-schema>
{code}

 # Find out the pageId of page "Welcome to Confluence" => e.g. 12345
 # Check the content properties of the page with the following command:
{code:java}
curl -u admin:admin -X GET "http://localhost:8090/rest/api/content/12345/property" | python -mjson.tool
{code}

 # The page shouldn't have any content properties yet. Now add content properties with the following command:
{code:java}
curl -i -u admin:admin -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "key" : "metadata", "value" : { "likes": 5 }}' http://localhost:8090/rest/api/content/12345/property
{code}

 # Check the content properties of the page again to make sure they've been added successfully:
{code:java}
curl -u admin:admin -X GET "http://localhost:8090/rest/api/content/12345/property" | python -mjson.tool
{code}

 # You should see the inserted content properties. Now try to use CQL to search by our indexed content properties:
{code:java}
http://localhost:8090/rest/api/content/search?cql=space%3Dds%20AND%20content.property%5Bmetadata%5D.likes%3C%3D5
{code}

 # The search should return the page "Welcome to Confluence". Now reindex Confluence as described here: [Rebuilding the search index|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/content-index-administration-148844.html#ContentIndexAdministration-Rebuildingthesearchindex]
 # Now execute the search again:
{code:java}
http://localhost:8090/rest/api/content/search?cql=space%20=%20ds%20AND%20content.property[metadata].likes%20%3C=%205
{code}

*No results found! All content properties are missing in the index after reindexing Confluence!*
h2. Expected result

All indexed content properties stay in the search index, even after reindexing Confluence.

Any help would be appreciated
h2. Root cause

ThreadLocalCache ({_}com.atlassian.confluence.cache.ThreadLocalCache{_}) is not initialized in reindexing threads. Let's look at how content properties are indexed.

Content properties are extracted in {_}com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.contentproperty.index.extractor.ContentPropertiesExtractor#addFields{_}. This method relies on _ThreadLocalCache_ to maintain permission exemptions. _ThreadLocalCache_ however needs to be initialized before it can be used, see {_}com.atlassian.confluence.cache.ThreadLocalCache#init{_}. We're doing this in scheduler threads ({_}com.atlassian.confluence.impl.schedule.caesium.JobRunnerWrapper#runJob{_}) which handle indexing for content updates, but not reindexing threads ({_}com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.ConcurrentBatchIndexer#accept{_}) for whole site reindexing.
h2. How to fix this bug properly?

Well, the fix should be very simple: just call _ThreadLocalCache#init_ in reindexing threads.
h2. Is there a workaround?

Not really a workaround but If you have control of a plugin's source code, there is a *hacky* way to index content properties properly during reindex without having to modify Confluence core: just add 2 extractors to the plugin:
 # An extractor *right before* (ie. priority > 900) _ContentPropertiesExtractor_ (priority = 900) and call _ThreadLocalCache#init_ inside it.
 # Another extractor *right after* (ie. priority < 900) _ContentPropertiesExtractor_ (priority = 900) and call _ThreadLocalCache#dispose_ inside it.

Prior to Confluence 7.14, these extractors need to implement the [extractor|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/extractor-module/] module. From 7.14 onward, they must implement the newer [extractor2|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/extractor2-module-tutorial/] module.
fields.summary: Content properties missing in search index after reindex of Confluence

h4. Summary

When running Confluence Directory synchronization in Data Center, the data center nodes will display the last synchronization from the individual Node, not the cluster-wide last sync time. an Admin looking at only one node may believe the synchronization did *not* happen, and mistakingly run the manual synchronization process. 
h4. Environment
 * Oracle 12c 12.1.0.2.0 - ojdbc7.jar driver
 * Confluence 5.10.8 Data Center

h4. *Steps to Reproduce*
 * Connect to LDAP/AD Server
 * Allow the system to sync
 * Observe the Sync time on Each Node

h4. Expected Result

Each Node should reflect the last time that the directory was synced *cluster-wide*
h4. *Actual Result*

Each Node reflects the last time the sync was run on *that node. See a2,jpg below:*

 * !a2.jpg|thumbnail!*

*And a3,jog below from the same cluster:*

!a3.jpg|thumbnail!

(i) *NOTE:*   The times are the same, but the dates are different. Reviewing these, an admin might believe that the sync did not run for a day.
h4. *Workaround*

There is no actual workaround other than a visual inspection of all nodes to verify the last run date of the actual synchronization from the nodes or to run the queries:
{code:java}
SELECT NEXT_RUN_TIME FROM SCHEDULER_CLUSTERED_JOBS AS JOB WHERE JOB.JOB_RUNNER_KEY LIKE %DirectoryPollerManager%;

SELECT * FROM SCHEDULER_CLUSTERED_JOBS AS JOB WHERE JOB.JOB_RUNNER_KEY LIKE %DirectoryPollerManager%;{code}
This will provide the next run time of the sync (which should be in the future) and all of the information about the job.

Hi,
we have installed Confluence and JIRA at our organisation and though neither are officially live yet, groups have been trialing the apps. 
Consequently content has been added to Confluence and multiple add-ons have been trialed before a decision is made as to the future of the apps and their associated add-ons.  Of course, to trial many add-ons effectively, teams need to add content to assess the usability and efficacy of the add-on.

Unfortunately this means that we now have a problem as our trial license for Excellentable has expired and one of our groups has used it but not saved the content elsewhere.

Hence we are unable to recover their content.
 # *Request*:  Can you advise how I can retrieve their content?
 # *Suggestion 1*:  ideally, all add-ons would allow the user to trigger a 24hr amnesty courtesy period once a license (trial or otherwise) expires to allow users to extract their content if they so desire.  Otherwise they are essentially blackmailed into buying a license to access their data/content or will have to accept the loss

 # *Suggestion 2*:  add a "Find Current Instances" button in the Add-ons page that allowed the user to locate all instances where the add-on has been used.  This would allow the user to assess how well-used the add-on really is and also locate each instance so that content can be extracted prior to a licence expiry.

So for our situation, if we could navigate to the Confluence add-ons page, click a "Find Current Instances" button for Excellentable , assess our usage, and then click a "24hr extension" button at a time that is convenient to us, it would allow us to review our content and decide whether it should be extracted.

Alternatively, getting all vendors of content based add-on to provide a basic extraction tool, that can be used post-license expiry, would get around this issue.

Otherwise users are essentially blackmailed into buying a license to extract their data/content, regardless of whether they would like to keep the add-on.

Cheers
Chris
